clinical_study.brief_title: Samples Procurement for Colorectal Cancer, Gastric Cancer, and Non-malignant Disease
clinical_study.official_title: Samples Procurement for Patients With Colorectal Cancer, Gastric Cancer, and Non-malignant Disease Undergoing Surgery

brief_summary.textblock: The purposes of this study are to collect and store samples including blood, normal and tumor tissue from patients with colorectal cancer or gastric cancer, to collect and store samples including blood and/or normal gastrointestinal tissue (if available) from patients with non-malignant disease (including, but not limited to, inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), gastric ulcer, hemorrhoids or hernia), and to create a database for the collected samples and allow access to relevant clinical information for current and future protocols.

primary_outcome.description: Once tissue is collected, those samples that have a confirmed diagnosis of disease by the pathologist will be used.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Colorectal cancer or gastric cancer patient
arm_group.description: Patients suffering from CRC or gastric cancer scheduled to have surgical resection of colon/rectum or stomach.
Patients suffering from non-malignant disease scheduled to have surgery.

intervention.intervention_name: No intervention will be given to patients.
intervention.description: Samples are collected at the time of a scheduled surgery that is part of normal treatment. This study will not have any impact on the care or treatment the patient receives.
intervention.arm_group_label: Colorectal cancer or gastric cancer patient

biospec_descr.textblock: Biospecimens will be analyzed to study, but not limited to, genomics, epigenomics, and proteomics.

study_pop.textblock: Participants who are planning to undergo surgery.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Any patient diagnosed with colorectal cancer, gastric cancer, non-malignant disease that requires undergoing surgery.
- Must be willing and able to provide informed consent.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Subjects whose comorbidities would preclude diagnostic or therapeutic intervention.
